section.title: This Manual's Audience
section.para: SystemBuilder is a product intended for Linux system administrators and build managers who need to build and deploy Linux-based appliances. Each part in this manual assumes you have a particular level of knowledge.

For Part I, "Basic SystemBuilder Usage," in addition to knowing how to create and edit XML files, manage a web server and create USB and CD/DVD boot media, you should have an intermediate skill level with the following components:

listitem.para: RPM package usage; and
YUM usage and configuration.

section.para: For Part II, "Robust Appliance Management," experience with version control systems, local mirror hosting, XPath and XInclude.

For Part III, "Advanced Appliance Concepts," key skills include understanding how to create RPM packages and package repositories and how to automate Anaconda installations using kickstart files, command line arguments and update images.

section.title: What's Not Covered in This Manual
section.para: This manual complements several SystemBuilder documents. The "Installation Instructions" and "Getting Started Guide" provide basic information about obtaining and installing SystemBuilder and creating a basic CentOS appliance. "Appliance Definition File Reference" (SDFR) contains the syntax for appliance definition file elements and attributes. Finally, SystemBuilder has a set of man pages explaining the systembuilder command, its options and the SystemBuilder configuration file, systembuilder.conf. This manual contains references to all four throughout the text.
These SystemBuilder documents are available at the Rendition Software SystemBuilder documentation website.

section.title: How to Read This Manual
section.para: The intent of the manual is to help you use SystemBuilder effectively to build and maintain appliances, update the appliance and customize the appliance installation. This is not a cookbook for various server appliance types, e.g. Samba, DNS, or LDAP. Rather, this manual takes the top-down approach, explaining the concepts before giving steps, commands and code examples that you can use to build, deploy and enhance your own appliances.

section.title: Conventions Used in This Manual
section.para: The document conventions are alphabetically listed below.

listitem.para: The Caution tag flags issues of importance.

caution.para: Using the 'dd' command to copy the diskboot.img file onto a USB key will destroy existing data on the device.

listitem.para: Command names in SystemBuilder or function names in other programs appear throughout the document.

Elements and attributes in XML are referred to by their XPath equivalents. The active node is always considered to be the root, appliance; thus, the first element in the XPath expression is the top-level element, while subsequent elements/attributes are its children. Top-level elements in the SDFR and their child elements use the parent/child/child format, while @attribute-names are preceded by an @ symbol. The assumed parent element is appliance. For more details on XPath syntax, see XML Path Language.

Within appliance file examples, the traditional XML comment tags "<!--" and "-->" contain notes. See Also .

section.title: Organization of This Manual
section.para: This manual contains three parts, each with an increasing level of complexity and detail.

listitem.para: Part I, "Basic SystemBuilder Usage," will help you start using SystemBuilder immediately.

"What Does SystemBuilder Do?" explains what an appliance is, how SystemBuilder helps you build it in a more efficient timely manner and the underlying architecture that makes this improved performance possible. The section also includes a "Glossary of Terms" explaining terms used within the SystemBuilder realm.

"Basic Usage: Getting the Job Done," covers the basic concepts for configuring the SystemBuilder build system, defining and deploying an appliance, running SystemBuilder and updating an appliance. As a use case model, these sections will help you create a basic Samba server appliance based on CentOS 5.
Part II, "Robust Appliance Management," will help you set up a managed appliance development and deployment environment using SystemBuilder as its cornerstone.

"Why Use SystemBuilder as part of a Production Environment?" explains implementing the development - staging - production environment within the content of building and deploying appliances using SystemBuilder. The Samba server appliance you created in Part I will have new features requirements to implement in Part II.

"Utilizing SystemBuilder within the Development - Staging - Production climate" discusses how SystemBuilder makes your life easier as a system or build administrator. Versioning appliance files and utilizing an object-oriented model through the XInclude mechanism for the appliance files are important usability features. Choosing the best location for storing and downloading an appliance via the web is another key concept.
Part III, "Advanced Appliance Concepts," will help you customize your appliances.
"Desiging the Appliance" targets the advanced system administrator, describing how to add custom release files.
"Managing Appliance Packages" discusses GPG checking and using GPG keys to sign your own packages.
"Booting Up an Appliance" gives you the opportunity to flex your automation muscles by implementing boot-up and kickstart files. Creating different images is another advanced feature.
